description.text:
This is a mount that allows a Raspberry Pi camera (v1 or v2) to be used in a telescope for astrophotography. The eyepiece will fit any 1.25" focuser. To use the Pi Camera for astrophotography you will need to remove the lens that covers the sensor, this can be done with a pair of long nosed pliers, carefully gripping the lens and rotating. YOU MUST GRIP THE CIRCULAR PART AND NOT THE SQUARE PART.

There are two files, one for the eyepiece that goes into the focuser and another for a cap that sits over the top, you will also need the following:

  • 4off M3x12 Cap Head Bolts
  • 4off M2x4 Cap Head Bolts

You may want to use a longer data cable that is available on the internet depending on how far away from your Pi you have the camera (mine is attached to the body of the telescope).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Fisher 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2

Infill:

15% rectilinear

Notes:

Printed well for me with a 200C setting for all layers, 0.2mm resolution but you can go finer (and I will for the final version).

Assembly

Once printed assembly is very simple, use the M2 bolts to attach the camera PCB to the cap (this assumes you have already removed the lens from the camera to enable photography to take place), the data cable should lie towards the edge with the cut-out. Ensure that the camera is pointing up. Next line up the eyepiece with the camera and use the 4 M3 bolts to secure the two together, ensure that the bolt heads are on the cap side as pictured. That's all there is to it.

description.text:
Can be used to hold a Luxeon LED Star Power LED.
Should fit into some old eumig Super 8 Projectors (e.g. MARK S 807) instead of the Projection Lamp (50mm diameter). Kept open at the side for some extra air circulation. Plus, has two extra connectors at the side, Fischertechnik compatible for other experimental setups.
The scond file (without the "*_ft" at the end) is a plain version without those extras. Print in ABS. However, as the Luxeon LEDs get pretty hot (I have a 3W), no guarantee, it will survive in all environments.

Print one of these.
Use two M3 screws and nuts to hold the Luxeon Star LED in position.
Add a "diffuser" at the bottom. E.g. the bottom of a yoghurt cup should work fine. Either attach it with some glue or just with the two M3 nuts.

description.text: In the 4 or 5 months I've been designing things this is the longest project I have done so far. this is a square rack mount that I made to attach some things on to the rack of my marimba. I don't know if all square racks have the same dimensions; I know it will work on a Yamaha and Pearl square racks because I have used Pearl mounts on Yamaha racks in the past (and currently). I wouldn't put anything heavy on the mounts I designed: 1 because it is plastic and 2 because it potentially hangs over my marimba. In the files are the 2 pieces to make the mount and some attachments that will fit on it. I haven't printed all of the attachments but am confident they should work. If you have problems let me know!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

always high

Infill:

40%

Notes:

More infill may be a good idea. The bottom half of the mount only needs supports while the top needs a raft and support. For the go pro and cowbell attachments a raft and support are also needed. I have only printed the go pro little guy attachment, but am confident the rest will work. I am currently designing faster than I can print and am excited to post this online. The only one with a different base that I designed is the tray; it shouldn't need a raft maybe support, but I have not printed this one yet. My plan is to ad more attachments over time.

Assembly

After removing rafts and support you will need 3 bolts and nuts. A 2 inch long 1/4 thick to connect the top and bottom pieces and two 2 1/2 inch long 1/4 thick to tighten the mount around the square rack and to attach the attachments. Not difficult to put together at all; if this isn't enough help let me know and I'll make a video.
The progression of how I reached the final product.

Design pukki34

Timelapse of printing https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ERfRmofW1VA

Version 0.4 is for 55mm 2-blade props.

Version 0.5 is for BN props up to ~58mm. Lightweight. Someone test print this

title: Prusa i3 mount for MK8 extruder and an E3D hotend

description.text:
So, you have a "cheap auction site" Prusa i3 and want to bin the supplied extruder and hot end so you can fit something a bit better.

Well, this bracket allows you to put a MK8 all metal LEFT version extruder and an E3D v6 or Lite6 hot end onto your printer.

Photo shows MK8 LEFT extruder and E3D Lite6 with Volcano fitted.

You will need
M3 x 30mm Socket Cap head bolts x 2
M3 x 25mm Socket Cap head bolts x 2
M3 x 12mm Socket Pan head bolts x 2
M3 Flat Washers x 4
M3 Nuts x 2

The distance between the mounting holes is 30mm

!!!!!! PLEASE NOTE !!!!!!
This mod WILL require a Z AXIS END STOP adjustment
!!!!!! YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED !!!!!!

Here's a link to my youtube video showing the design and how to assemble this bracket
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ubpQr5c1oN4

Prusa i3

Notes:

I printed at 0.3 layer height with 2 shells, but that is with a 0.8mm nozzle, so probably 3 shells and 0.2 layer with a standard 0.4 nozzle.

Support is needed, I printed with the slide part against the bed so it came out smooth and the arch between the slide and the thumb tab was supported. Fitment was almost perfect, cleaned out the groove for the cable, and hit one part that was binding with a scrap of sand paper and it slides smoothly. Probably just always be conscious that it is printed and try to be careful with it and it should be plenty strong, just don't wrench on it, and keep your cable smooth.

I placed the broken pieces of the lever on a flat bed scanner and also placed a credit card, I then imported this into fusion 360 and used the calibrate option on the picture off of the credit card to make the size perfect and traced a sketch on top of the picture, then extruded this and began modeling the rest with my calipers.

author: mrmuffin

title: Linear actuator using geared retract motor.

description.text:
I designed parts to make an actuator from these geared retract motor units I have.

This is the motor unit I used:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Worm-Motor-Control-Board-for-Retractable-Electric-Landing-Gear-/172104935631

EDIT:
After playing with it for a while I noticed that they will reverse if they are blocked or if the channel is flipped when they are unpowered. I bought my motor units six months ago, so this issue may be fixed now, but for now I can't recommend buying these motors unless they are confirmed fixed.

Assembly:
1 - Thread the plunger onto the M3 shaft half way down. A nut can be slid into the slot on the underside of the plunger for a stronger thread.
2 - Insert the plunger end and the switch board into the housing.
3 - Carefully slide the board and motor unit into the housing. The board should be pushed in by the edge of the gearbox, and the gearbox should be oriented with the protruding small gear pointing up towards the board/empty space so that it doesn't rub against the housing wall.
4 - Push everything all the way in.
5 - Attach the bracket. If it's printed from anything other than nylon, it can be warmed with a heat gun prior to installation to prevent breaking as the lugs are spread.
6 - Insert an M3 set screw on the bottom of the housing to lock the gearbox in place, and attach short M3 screws to the hinge point if necessary.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gzUJdTfH-gY" ></iframe>

author: tahustvedt

description.text:
This is a remix of Timogiles' version. I changed the coil holders so that they are cut from acrylic and glued together. A 1/4 inch bolt is used in the center of the bottom, middle, and top pieces. They are glued and the bolt allows for easy attachment to an electric drill for winding the coils. After, the bolt is taken out and the two screw holes attach it to the bottom board.  
I chose the acrylic coil holders vs the 3d printed because the printed version would need huge amounts of cleanup or a 2 nozzle printer with support material. Also, they couldn't be hooked to an electric drill for easy coil winding.  
I modified the main assembly making it smaller and using S-shaped springs. The mirror section is to be cut out and a first surface mirror should be placed in the square hole and recessed so the surface is  at the midway depth point. This ensures no odd Trig problems (curved lines when they should be straight). You could also use a regular mirror glued in the middle and just not laser cut the center. But the first surface is nicer because you don't loose 20% of your laser energy intensity by going through the acrylic and back out.

comments.text: Nice work!  I thought about doing the hinges like that but thought that allow the whole assembly to be pulled in the z direction toward the electromagnets.  I'll be curious to see how this performs.  I'm still trying to improve my design as well.

title: Realistic Sunfish Jointed Swimbait Fishing Lure

description.text:
NOTE - This is a failed project!

I'm giving up on this design and moving on to other things.... I'm leaving the files up just encase anyone else is brave enough and wants to experiment with it.

This is a Realistic Sunfish Jointed Swimbait lure I am designing and was my first try at modeling something in Fusion 360 so thing still might change.

The lure Assembles similar to my my Crankbait Fishing Lure.

Mirror the STL's in your slicer for the other half of each side.

It can be painted to mimic many types of typical Sunfish. (E.g. - Bluegill, Pumpkinseed, Rockbass, even Crappie.) I choose to go with the pumpkinseed pattern after the fish its was modeled after.

UPDATES

  • 10-17-16 - Added Sunfish Lure Body V3 = Pectoral Fin and raised 3D Gill.

  • 10-19-16 - Tested Sunfish Lure Body V3 yesterday and it turned out to be kind of a DUD. It really didn't swim like a swimbait and it didn't have any action at all. The one I cut out for the plexiglass a lip worked pretty well so I will probably just add a lip to the design and re-upload all the files. Until I do don't waste your time on this one yet!

  • 06-04-17
    Added Sunfish Lure Body Lip = Body with Printed Lip
    Added Sunfish Lure Body Clear Lip = Body for use with Clear Plexiglass Lip.
    (I have yet to fully test these yet.)

  • 06-05-17
    Added a couple of Lip Templates
    (neither of these is the same lip as the printed lip version)
    You can use these to trace onto a piece of Plexiglass or even print them and glue them to the body.

  • 07-16-17
    Tested out the new lip designs and I'm still NOT happy with them. The larger lipped one has way to much wobble and the smaller one it very erratic and only works at very slow retrieves.

  • 08-22-17
    Tested out a single piece version today but this one was a the worst yet. This was the final try and It's time to give up on this design and move on to better things.... I'm leaving up the files just encase anyone else wants to experiment.

70%

Notes:

The first one I printed at 20% and it ended up being to light so it floated (which isn't what you want in a swimbait.) so I reprinted it at 70% infill and that was enough to get it to sink.

The one with the lip was me trying to salvage the one that floated. I cut the relief for the lip with a hobby saw. If it preforms well with the lip I will add that version eventually.

description.header: From actual Fish to Printed Lure.
description.text: The lure was designed from a picture of I fish a caught on my other printed lures. The basic shape was done in Fusion360's sculpt environment with details (fins) added with normal sketches and extrudes. The wire forming on this one is a little trickier because of the hinge so wire forming pliers are highly recommended. The lure is printed flat in halves and BB's are added for wieght and the wire forms tested for fit. The front half is glue together first, then the hinge pin is inserted in the hinge loops and the rear halves are glued together while sandwiching the pin in place. The assembled lure ready for paint. After airbrushing and sealing with epoxy the lures are ready to test.

New and Improved bottle opener. This opener is much more ergonomic, as well as supporting both US quarters and pennies. penny-opener.stl - this is the STL for a penny based bottle opener. small, compact, cheap.
quarter-opener.stl - this is the STL for a quarter based bottle opener. bigger, beefier, a bit more expensive.
Simply print it out, insert coin, and enjoy a nice cold beer!

comments.text: I've tried out a good few bottle opener designs over the years. The only one that comes anywhere close to this simple classic in actual effectiveness on a wide range of beers is the "Brain" bottle opener by Ahasuerus http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24345http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... so I'm prepared to call this design a classic.

description.text:
I needed a carpet protector for the small table my printer stands on.
The table legs were sinking into the carpet, and this object helped to distribute the weight.
Needless to say the carpet will thank me for it.... I have included the 123design file also.

I printed in ABS with more perimeters and infill for strength.
I think i used about 4-5 perimeters and an infill of 0.4 (going by memory)
As always use your judgement, and what might work best for you based on your needs. It is about 90mm in diameter at the base and has a 35mm Square pocket for the table foot.

title: DJI Style 450 Arm Fully Flat - Easy to print

description.text:
Modified design of another contributor to allow for 100% flat top side, makes it easier to print without need for rafting or supports. Enjoy.  
Credit to Pintokitkat for Original Design, I will be making more updates to this original, as legs are staple to have on hand for our Quads.
Print at 45 % infill and .20mm layer height and 3 Shells for a good solid arm. Can increase infill if you want more strength. Standard Print mode on Replicator 2 or 2x.

author: Coozco

description.text:
This is a pan car based on the Serpent S240. A modified design was created by Ivan Martin found here _ http://myprotorc.blogspot.it/?m=1. His design took the S240 and shrunk it down to 102mm wheel base for use along side the Kyosno Mini-z. Ivan shared his files with me so I could modify it for my own personal use which I've uploaded here. My design was made with Tinkercad.

The top plate is connected using the 12mm spacers from a stand-off kit found on Amazon. The knuckle axles are pulled from broken stock MR-03 and MR-02 knuckles. The mid-mount motor mount and differential are also from the Kyosho Mini-Z series. The lexan body is the PN Pancar.
Parts List -
+3 Narrow wheels(Front)
MR-02 King Pins and C-Clips
Kyosho MR-02/03 Knuckle Axles
Kyosho MR-03 Stock Springs
DS-919MG Servo
LU-CC 180Pcs M2 Black Nylon Spacers Hex Nut Screw Stand-off Plastic Accesories Assortment Kit
PN Damper Spacer
PN Damper Plate
PN Damper Screw Washers
Kyosho Stock Damper and Spring
Kyosho MR-02/03 MM Motor mount
Kyosho Stock Differential
+3 11mm Wheels(Rear)
MR-02/03 Bearing Set
Various Screws from MR-02/03 Stock Kits

All of my progress and projects can be found on my Facebook page- https://www.facebook.com/byebyeracing/

title: Full Shock Mount for MXL V67 (and other condenser mics)

description.text:
This is a remix (?)  or actually an add-on for stcredzero's shock mount.  
I added an inner mic mount for a 47mm (-ish) diameter microphone.

Print 2 copies of: ShockMountHalf.stl
glue the halves together, bottom-to-bottom (top/bottom as printed). Print one each of: ShockMountCenterHalf and ShockMountCenterHalfFlipped. Glue the 2 center halves together top-to-top (top/bottom as printed). add 10 small rubber band type gaskets and you've got yourself a $50+ shock mount for about $2.00 in plastic and a few bucks at the hardware store.

The lovable, curious, sentient, walking AI tanks of death from Ghost in the Shell Stand Alone Complex.  The Tachikomas are only characters in either series who the audience develops any emotional attachment to at all.  And they kill them horribly... twice.  
Now you can build your own very own Tachikoma.  It will loyally follow you on your adventures, while inquiring cheerfully about the meaning of life and the nature of its own existence.  
(Remodeled for 3d printing based on the excellent work of ALM Model Works on 3d Warehouse)  
(Update 1/19/2015 - I have added a thin shelled version of the Tachikoma for people who would like to replicate my experiments using a Form 1+)
You will need to turn on support material to print this.

description.text:
Telescope eyepiece for the Raspberry Pi and camera module. More details at the project's home page:
https://github.com/dmopalmer/PiPiece

PiPiece
======= Electronic eyepiece for telescopes etc. using the Raspberry Pi camera module. Homepage
========
The latest version of this project will be at its homepage
https://github.com/dmopalmer/PiPiece Parts
===== This is an electronic eyepiece for a telescope or other optical system, built from a Raspberry Pi and its camera module. (You can currently get a Model A Raspberry Pi and camera module for $40 as a bundle, e.g. http://www.alliedelec.com/Search/ProductDetail.aspx?SKU=70315057) You will also need an SD card with the operating system, power supply, and case for the Raspberry Pi. For convenience and cordlessness, you can add a USB WiFi dongle and a USB battery. Print a drawtube and a backplate for the appropriate eyepiece tube size for your telescope. (Common sizes are 0.965", 1.25", and 2.0".) Use black filament to reduce internal reflections. The Makerbot Customizer on Thingiverse did not work correctly, so I have manually generated all part x size permutations. If you want a different size, look at the the files in parts_and_sizes_scad.zip to see how to do it with OpenSCAD. A couple of small-diameter nuts and bolts hold the two printed parts together and onto the case to make a single solid unit. (I used #3-48 x 3/4 inch bolts.) Assembly Instructions
===================== http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:181310 has some pictures that might be helpful. You will probably have to drill out the various holes. On the drawtube component, there are 4 holes for the mounting pins from the backplate, and the relief cavity for the LED on the camera module. Then clamp the pieces together onto the lid of your Raspberry Pi case, and drill out the mounting screw holes for the appropriate sized bolts you are using. Cut a slot in the Raspberry Pi case to accomodate the cable. The spacing between the holes is the same as for the Raspberry Pi version 2 mounting holes, so if you don't want to use a case you can mount the assembly directly to the board using stand-offs. Carefully remove the lens from the camera module, breaking or scraping away the glue and unscrewing the lens. The system is now susceptible to dust, so try to keep it clean. Put everything together, slide it into an eyepiece tube, and try it out. Focusing and Pointing
====================== The focus is very sensitive and the focal point is probably going to be quite far from what it is with your favorite eyepiece. Use an eyepiece to focus your telescope on something nearby, then further away, and note which direction you turn the focus knob. With this imager you will probably have to turn quite a ways in the same direction (well 'beyond infinity') to get it in focus. A daytime scene is probably the best way to start. When the system is out of focus, you will probably see nothing but a uniform flat field, apart from the shadows of all the dust that got on the imager. The field of view is very small due to the size of the imager. The sensor size is 3.67 x 2.74 mm (2592 x 1944 pixels at 1.4 microns each.) A 2000 mm focal length telescope (e.g. a Celestron 8) will have a 6.3 x 4.7 arcminute FOV. (The Moon is 30 arcminutes across. Venus and Jupiter can get up to ~an arcminute across and Mars half that at the closest points of their orbits.) Therefore you will want to carefully align your finderscope. Software
======== You want to turn off the camera LED to prevent light leakage. Add the following in /boot/config.txt on the Raspberry Pi's SD card:
disable_camera_led=1

description.text:
Voici une fin de course mécanique Axe Z pour Hephestos 2

Le détecteur inductif détecte le plateau ou plus exactement le métal sous le verre.

Si vous oubliez de monter le plateau et que vous demandez une fonction au panneau, la tête va descendre afin de mesurer le 0 Z et ne va jamais le trouver :letmethink:
Le risque est de casser le détecteur inductif sur le support plateau ou de sortir des rails les roulements Z... :((

Le principe de cette modification est de limiter mécaniquement la course de la tête avec 2 écrous positionnés quelques mm en dessous de la position 0 de la buse.

De cette façon, en cas d'absence du plateau en verre, la tête ne pourra pas descendre trop bas et éviter une éventuelle casse.

De part et d'autre des vis Z, les deux écrous serrés ensembles sont recouverts d'un cache qui a une fonction d'amortisseur en cas de choc (PLA contre métal) et pour l'esthétique un corps qui recouvre les écrous.

Montage :
Mettre les deux écrous et le cache sur la tige filetée de l'axe Z (cache en haut). Vissez les écrous pour descendre au plus bas (contre l'accouplement du moteur) Positionnez votre tête à 0mm et tracez un repère sur la vis Z à la hauteur du bloc alu tenant le X. Remontez votre tête à 50mm. Vissez de chaque coté le premier écrou à 3mm en dessous des repères. En maintenant le premier écrou vissez le suivant et serrez-le avec le premier. Glissez en bas le cache pour cacher le tout.
Contrôlez votre 0 et la position de la butée.
Vous ne courrez plus aucun risque d''oublier de monter votre plateau

Vous souhaitez d'autres idées, c'est ici http://premium-forum.fr/viewforum.php?f=1

title: Very thin iPhone 6/6S case with tactile feel - Flower of Life design
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a thin iPhone 6/6s case, designed completely from ground up using Apple's case specifications, It has the same curve and corner rounding of the phone itself.

iPhone 7 case is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404836

The tolerance are tight, it is a trade-off between tight fitting, but just flexible enough to snap over the phone. It was designed for rigid filaments,

This is a very slim design, which is my personal preference, but such that it still can can be put face down without scratching the screen.

I've made several organic patterns, but posted the Flower of Life here.

My filament preference is for wood filament for a more natural look and feel., It also has a tactile feel to it and can be sanded down

For printing I have added anti-warp discs, just snap then off. Any form of warping will prevent the phone from fitting properly. After printing clean any residue or whatever from the inside curve, any blobs will also prevent the phone from fitting properly.

I printed at 0.2mm layer and at 80-100% infill..

Please note the license, it is for personal use only, with no commercialization

Update 2

  • increased area around camera
  • added more support at bottom corners

My girlfriend ask me for an incense holder one day and I decided to surprise her and made this simple, practical and funny design. I've divided the object to make it easier to clean the ashes. I've made 2 versions of the tray for each person preference or depending of the work area of the printer. One version 200mm long and the other divided in two part tray. I've printed the Incense Holder in my felixprinter using Sfact - Normal quality - no support. Printed in white PLA and then I painted the Incense Holder with some water-based acrylic paints.
My girlfriend loved it and we are still using the incense holder to this day. Hope more people like it too!

I won 1st prize on FELIXprinters 3D design contest 2015 with this design.

title: Anti-vibration feet for GEEETech i3 Pro B with 8mm acrylic frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was seeing a lot of vibration dampening feet, or people with foam under their printers, or other methods of silencing their printer.

I have taken the designs of bernbout and kb3lnn and combined them so that you can easily out vibration dampening feet under your GEEETech i3 Pro B without making modifications to it to actually mount something to them.

These feet together with the decoupler rings for the stepper make the printer very quiet.
http://www.ebay.nl/itm/231992705339

The only sound coming from the printer now are the noises from the fans.

Try the new V2 of this design
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476818

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

GEEETech i3 Pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

15%

Notes:

print everything once, except for the parts for the front, those are indicated with "Anti-Vibration Feet - Damper/Feet - FrontLR.stl".
These need to printed 2 times each, as the front parts are identical and are just "mounted" the other way around.

Use a M4x6mm nut and M4 bolt to fasten the feet together with the damper.
Then just slide the part under the correct corners and you're done.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jZ0V7XEvUji

This is an adapter for the motorcycle blinker.
On some motorcycles (like mine Triumph) the blinker are mounted with M6 screw and an additional hole for the cables. Most of the aftermarket blinker comes with a M8 screw and cables pass trough the screw.
With this adapter you can mount M8 threaded blinker on a M6 threaded motorcycle.
I've not road tested the adapter, try at your own risk. I suggest to print it with high resistance material (such as ABS) with 100% infill.
For Triumph Tiger 1050 sport dedicated blinker holder, take a look on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1816236
As prescribed from GPL license, I include the "source" freeCAD file and a copy of the license.

description.text: Stone network lampshade

I made these bats for my wife to decorate our house for Halloween. They are simple silhouettes with a 3rd dimension added for printing. I also added a loop at the top of each for hanging. The loop isn't perfectly balanced so you may want to move it around.

I've uploaded each whole bat and the sliced bats for printing on smaller printers. I made it so each bat half will snap together, but if you put it outside in the wind I recommend you glue the halves together, I found the snaps alone are not strong enough if the wind causes the bat to strike the side of your house.

To balance the bats better I found that I could change the infill percentage to adjust the weight. I set the infill for the smaller half to 30% and the infill for the larger half 20%, by doing this the bat will hang balanced without a need to move the loop.

comments.text: Thanks! I print at 300% zoomed, they are very good for Halloween party:D
comments.author: predator75

title: RR-Evo Delta 3D Printer - [E2] upgraded with Rostock parts

description.text:
This is next step of RR-EVO's evolution. Moving plywood parts replaced with 3d-printed.

Previous step:
RR-Evo Delta 3D Printer - [E1] plywood version

Next steps:
RR-Evo Delta 3D Printer - [E3] hot-end mount

Once I got the device printing I started making parts to replace plywood ones.

All the parts are of original Rostock design except vertical carriages. The following modifications were made in carriages:

  • added couple of 'ears' to hold end-stop screws at positions that correspond plywood version of carriages;
  • removed standard belt holder (instead I developed separate tensioner);

As you can see on photos, quality of parts I got was quite awful. That can be explained with several factors:

  • lack of experience in 3d-printing;
  • very poor calibration of the machine, not only extrusion but geometry also - that's lack of knowledge of delta mechanics;

Anyway, I got significant improvement with replaced parts.

The tensioners fastened to carriages in place. I used M3 bolts and 'glue' (ABS dissolved in acetone). I tried to develop carriage with integrated tensioner, but that design I got would be hard to print. So I decided to leave it separate.

The 'glue' was also used to fix some defects of parts and to fix nuts in different places.

Along to the improvements, some major issues still present in this construction:

  • the carriages are still on two linear bearings (swinging) - better to use carriages sitting on 3 bearings (or at least 2 longer bearings);
  • due to bad calibration of geometry, printed parts had wrong and inconsistent sizes, that brought significant troubles into calibration process of updated version - spend as much time for calibration as you can to get better result. I was impatient... that was stupid.

author: turi84

title: Improved Replacement Impeller for Top Fin PowerHead 30

description.text:
The Top Fin PowerHead 30 is an inexpensive (cheaply made), pump to move aquarium water.   I purchased two of these things and even when they were new, they were not very impressive.  After a month or so, they quit working completely.  
I took them apart to find that the impeller had broken.  Worse yet, it seemed that the thing had been designed to work poorly.  Maybe they didn't want to outshine the next model up or something.  
So I redesigned the impeller.  The original one was tiny and only filled a small portion of the chamber it was in.  I increased the size significantly to use more of the available space.    In the photos the original is on the left, and my model is on the right.  
After installing these parts, the power heads are pushing water like they never have before.  Much better than when they were new.  I've only been running them a few days, so I can't say much about how long they will last, but if I find improvements are needed, I'll post updates.  
If anyone else uses these, please let me know if they work for you.  
[PetSmart, if you use this design, I expect some free fish or something!]  
Update1: One of them cracked, so I made the wall about as thick as I can and still have it fit.
Print the impeller with the fins down.   Support is not necessary.  I used rafting because there isn't much area on the plate, but you might not need that either.

description.text:
Every Portabee user know the wiggling Z-axis Problem. This is my second Version of a Stabilizer. After the installation, you can print 75 mm high. You only need: 1 x M6 x 20cm Threaded rod
4 x M6 Locknuts
4 x M6 Washers 4 x M3 x 16mm screws
4 x M3 nuts If you have suggestions or critic - write me!
Belt clamps for Huxley 3d printer

The STL is for GT2 belts, but the openSCAD file is included so you can modify it for other sizes.  
Belt ends are looped through two printed blocks positioned so that they are within about 1".  The belts are held in place using removable printed clips that force the belt's teeth to lock togoether when doubled over.  Bolts are passed through the blocks, and the belt can be adjusted by tightening the bolts.  
The design does not depend on tooth spacing (just that there are teeth).  Only the belt height, width, and doubled height should need to be adjusted for other belt sizes.

Needed parts:
2 x 1.25 or 1.5" #6 bolts
2 x #6 nuts 0) Print the parts with 0.4 layer height or less. Drill out the bolt holes if necessary. 1) Thread the belt through the clip, hook side up (see 1st picture). 2) Thread the belt through the block, so it is doubled over on itself (2nd picture). The ends should be coming out of the side with the indents (nut cut-outs). 3) Thread the doubled over belt through the clip. You may need to use a small flat-head screwdriver or similar to keep the ends together so they fit through the hole. Pull the belt tight on the block and push the clip forward until it snaps over the block. 4) Repeat steps 1 & 2 for the other side of the belt. Slide the block around so that it is within about 1" of the first block when you pull the belt tight. 5) Place two #6 nuts behind the holes on the first block. Put two bolts through the other block. Repeat step 3 for this block, and snap the 2nd clip in place. 6) Put the two pieces together and tighten the bolts evenly to tension the belt. In theory zip ties can be used in place of the bolts? Use customizer to adjust for other belt sizes. Alternatively, download the openscad file. In theory only the belt width, belt height, and belt doubled height should need to be changed if you are using #6 screws.

After testing some 3D printed dice I discovered that square corners, not round or truncated corners, make the most balanced 3D printed dice. Also hollow centers were better than filled. So I made this. The square one scored a chi-squared of 14 after 30 rolls, the truncated one scored a 30, meaning the square corners is among the most fair 3D printed hollow dice I've tried. See http://joesmakerbot.blogspot.com/2013/10/testing-3d-printed-dice-fairness-chi.html for more infomation. If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays

description.text:
I just didn't like the skeeton design on this one, so...
The larger sheath should fit with a molle type pattern on your backpack or tactical vest. Prints without supports or brim - the large sheath comes with it's own support - just cut that away after print. Use M3 allen-head screws and standard nuts (black, of course ;-)

The sheaths are very tight whe you slide in the knife for the first time. Push the knife to the stop, and let it in there over night. It wil be hard to pull out still, but only the first time. After that the fit is perfect.

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 or better

Infill:

15-20%, 25% on the scales

Notes:

You may need to open the screw holes with a 3.2mm drill bit (1/8")

Here are two designs include with this model. One has a strategically weak center section on each of the connecting rings. This is so that separately printed pieces can be attached by first crushing the weakened section with a pair of pliers and then pulling the extra plastic free. Some sanding of the edges might be necessary to attach two pieces together.

There is also a version that has no weakened part in the rings for stronger pieces. When chaining piece together makes sure the two pieces are not intersected with each other. The pieces above were printed with 100% infill, but this not necessary four piece integrating, 50% works just as well.

Good luck! I am happy to receive feedback.
